titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thomas W. Streeter Collection of Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons Catalogs
Streeter (Thomas W.) Collection of Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons Catalogs

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Thomas W. Streeter collection of Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons catalogs

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Collection consists of Thomas W. Streeter's annotated copies of sale and exhibition catalogs issued by New York City rare book dealer Edward Eberstadt (1883-1958) and his sons, Lindley and Charles, during their careers as antiquarian booksellers. The collection includes more than 90 catalogs, announcements, and sales lists issued by three businesses-- the Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons-- between 1929 and 1965.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Thomas W. Streeter Collection of Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons Catalogs is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Thomas W. Streeter Collection of Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons Catalogs. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

bioghist.head: THOMAS W. STREETER (1883-1965)
bioghist.p: Thomas W. Streeter (1883-1965), lawyer and businessman, is known for his Bibliography of Texas and his work in the field of Americana. Born in Concord, New Hampshire, on July 20, 1883, Streeter graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord in 1900, and subsequently earned degrees from Dartmouth College (B.L., 1904) and Harvard Law School (LL.B., 1907). Streeter began practicing law in Boston and married Ruth Cheney in 1917. The couple had four children.

In 1917 Streeter moved to New York and began a career in business and finance. He eventually became president of the American International Corporation. Though Streeter retired from active business in 1939 to devote himself to collecting Americana, his interest in early American history and collecting was already established. While serving as chairman of the board of Simms Petroleum Corporation from 1923 to 1930, he took advantage of business trips to Texas to locate and acquire materials relating to Texas history. In 1936 rare items from his collection were exhibited at the Texas Centennial in Dallas and in 1939, his collection was showcased at the opening of the San Jacinto Monument and Museum. Streeter published a bibliography of selected items from his collection in 1952, titled Americana-Beginnings . Over the next five years, Streeter published the five-volume Bibliography of Texas, 1795-1845 . After completing the exhaustive work, he sold his Texas collection to Yale University's Collection of Western Americana.

As reflected in Americana-Beginnings , Streeter collected extensively in many areas of American history. Before his death, which occurred in Morristown, New Jersey, on June 12, 1965, Streeter developed plans to auction most of his personal collection. The auction took place in 7 sales at Parke-Bernet Galleries, New York City, between October 25, 1966, and October 22, 1969. The catalog for the sale, titled "The celebrated collection of Americana formed by the late Thomas Winthrop Streeter..." was based on Streeter's notes about his books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Thomas W. Streeter Collection of Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons Catalogs consists of more than 90 Americana-related book catalogs, supplements, sales lists, and exhibition catalogs issued by New York City rare book dealer Edward Eberstadt (1883-1958) and his sons, Lindley and Charles, between 1929 and 1965. The Eberstadt companies represented in the collection are the Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons. Thomas Streeter lightly annotated many of the catalogs in this collection, both listing on the cover and marking inside the catalogs items of interest, as well as occasionally correcting or supplementing the text. His penciled handwritten dates are the basis for the bracketed supplied dates in the box and folder listing.

Series I, Catalogs
, (Boxes 1-7) contains publications by three of the Eberstadts' bookselling companies and is organized into 3 subseries: Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons. Within each subseries, numbered publications are listed first in ascending order. Unnumbered publications follow. Many of the catalogs are general lists of Americana items, but some were based around particular geographical or historical themes. Publication titles have been transcribed. The collection includes a number of advance copies of catalogs, as well as two exhibition catalogs that Edward Eberstadt & Sons published in 1958 for exhibitions at the Fort Worth Art Center and the Dallas Public Library.

Series II, Other Material
, (Box 7) consists of a few clippings related to Edward Eberstadt & Sons's 1941 publication of Northwest Coast (Catalog No. 119), as well as a stapled handmade booklet titled "A Few 'Kind Words'", containing photostat reproductions of letters from rare book librarians offering congratulations to the firm on the fine quality of their work.
